message: Been using the Microsoft Comfort Keyboard 2000 (http://www.amazon.com/Microsoft-Comfort-Curve-Keyboard-B2L-00002/dp/B0009ZBRS0) for a while now - It has very little travel on the keys.
so whats everyone fave keyboard?
Logitech G11 - love it for the macros on the G buttons - http://blog.collins.net.pr/2010/12/logitech-g11-macro-alttab-problem.html
The DSI Poly Evolver is pretty great. :D
Microsoft comfort curve
Been using this thing for a few years.http://www.microsoft.com/hardware/mouseandkeyboard/ProductDetails.aspx?pid=043  comfy but nothing sp
Special
Lil apple Bluetooth keyboard is my fave

For all-day typing I definitely prefer mechanical switches, currently using a Filco Tenkeyless with Cherry browns (http://geekhack.org/showthread.php?t=15215). Pretty happy with regular Apple Aluminum too, for laptops or when you don't want to wake your SO in the middle of the night :)

I currently have a Logitech G19, and I like it, but the best keyboard I ever had was a Logitec y-re20.  The last time I had to buy one I bought two, cause they'd just been discontinued, but they're all gone now. :'(
apple keyboard? anyone used it for windows?.. i heard u have to map keys and all..
Filco tenkeyless here, with cherry black switches. Nice clean linear action.
I also use the little apple Bluetooth kbd when appropriate.
I like QWERTY keyboard :D
microsoft sidewinder x6. i love the detachable key pad.
When I switch from a dell/ibm (pre-lenovo) laptop to a pre-unibody macbook pro I remember having those "what a nice keyboard" moments for a few weeks
Logitech DiNovo Media Desktop.  I have three of them, and am terrified they'll all die and I won't be able to replace them anymore. The new ones aren't as good.
Kinesis Advantage... best keyboard on earth, if you're willing to cough up $250
Das Keyboard - no letters printed on keycaps, totally black
Happy Hacking Keyboard Professional 2 (http://flic.kr/p/6qjo7F). Anything else not it, a comparable Realforce model, or a Model M are just toys.
+1 for Microsoft Comfort Curve 2000. I also used a Logitech DiNovo for a while (both on the mac and PC) and overall gorgeous design, but not very comfy as MS Comfort.
Apple Keyboard FTW <3
Dad Keyboard!
discontinued now, had to buy it used
apple wired compact keyboard
@Stammy Did you remember to stockpile a couple for the future?
Logitech Ultra-X Premium Keyboard
Before switching to Mac keyboard i used Mitsumi Keyboard several years. It was somehow precursor to mac keyboard: http://www.shopeio.com/inventory/images/KFKEA4XT.jpg . I remember buying 10 of them.
Apple Keyboard (wired and wireless). Also works great on Windows.

Gold Touch keyboard saved my life. http://bit.ly/hvPmgI  I have had RSI issues for a few years and this keyboard has been key in my recovery (at least so I believe).  The drawback is if you work in an office, be prepared for ev-ry-one to make some silly comment about your keyboard.  Worth it tho. :)
At work I use (and love) the Apple Keyboard(wired), at home I use the Matias Tactil Pro 3 which is great but so noisy it's unusable in a work environnement;
@JazzyChad w00t! Got one too: http://www.daskeyboard.com/ But the silent one. Otherwise my Friends in the Office would go Crazy ;)

I also used a Razor Gaming Keyboard, but for Rapid Typing not Gaming. As long as the Keys are mechanical it really gets pleasant typing on them. I had a similar experience on this one: http://store.razerzone.com/store/razerusa/en_US/pd/productID.211324200/categoryId.35156900 as with my DasKeyboard. There is also an Ultimate edition with Backlit Keys. But 80$ for the simpler modell is very fair.
Microsoft Natural, the one with a wire. The only thing it's missing there are F-keys split in 3 groups of 4 instead of 2 groups of 6.
Unicomp Model M... i try to type less at night ;)
Apple's small wired keyboard, International qwerty layout
Microsoft's Natural Keyboard is the only Microsoft product that I completely adore and would never consider using anything else.  My wrists say thank you!
Logitech Illuminated, not because it's illuminated
Apple's small wireless keyboard is quite nice. I also have the full wired keyboard at my office, but I don't like it nearly as much.
@Vasil Me too
Kinesis Contoured Advantage Qwerty/Dvorak http://kinesis-ergo.com/images/kb_adv-blk720x471.jpg
http://kinesis-ergo.com/
Same as @jazzychad and @loganlinn for me. I have the labelled one at work in case someone else needs my station while I'm out.

Kinesis Freestyle with VIP addon. It's my favorite so far. I use the Dvorak layout. (Didn't really like certain things about the Advantage and returned it.) http://www.kinesis-ergo.com/images/freestyle-vip-front_690x228.jpg

I use my Macbook Pros keyboard because the keys have so little travel in them and aren't too soft. I totally hate my MS Natural 4000 that was recommended elsewhere in the thread. Horrible spacebar, too much travel in the keys and require more push effort which then give way and lead to me having a VERY tiring typing experience. (Aside: I'm more sensitive to good and bad keyboards as I have a muscle condition and the likes of the MS 4000 destroy me)
I have a Das Keyboard Ultimate model S and the previous model, the Das Keyboard II
Gotta' be the aluminium Apple keyboards. Super simple and looks great.
same as @kross - it might look weird, but it's not just good for ergonomics, it's pretty efficient too with the keys under your thumbs
Nice to see the variety. I'll also add alps black switches like in a AT101W are also a joy to use.
IBM Model M, wonderful piece of kit, although my neighbours are somewhat less appreciative especially if I'm typing quickly

I used to use the Apple wireless aluminium keyboard, but switched to the wired one, as no need to replace batteries.
Also, I learnt the hard way that OS X server doesn't turn on bluetooth during installation, which makes entering the serial quite fun ;p
Logitech Wave
Apples bluetooth keyboard is the best keyboard i've tried. Wish their mice were as good :)

I'm a big fan of the Microsoft Natural 4000. I have yet to find something I like better. An ergonomic keyboard took me a few weeks to fully adjust to, but once I did there was no looking back.

http://i76.photobucket.com/albums/j30/fjf314/1352023261_1fe98f7d7d.jpg
Anyone tried the razer black widow mechanical? I'm thinking of getting one.
Steelseries 7G
@Vasil never try razer's mechanical, but i loved my mechanical keyboard. now i'm just stuck with whatever came with apple's notebook...
I'm with @JohnFail.  I haven't tried all the others, but the Microsoft Natural 4000 is the best I've laid hands on.
@JohnFail I've heard a lot of good feedback about Microsoft Ergonomic keyboard.
@alagu A friend I used to work with had one, and after how much he raved about it I figured I would try one for myself when I needed a new keyboard. For $40, it's a steal.
Logitech illuminated wireless keyboard for me
http://usb.brando.com/prod_img/zoom/UKEYB004800_01_L.jpg
I like really tiny keyboards - firefly used to be a good one, but I couldn't find it in stores, so I've settled with the elephant - http://usb.brando.com/elephant-slim-keyboard_p01663c034d015.html
@surajreddy That's probably something I should use considering my current lack of desk space.
http://www.daskeyboard.com/images/products/2.jpg
http://www.daskeyboard.com/

Sidewinder X6, detachable macro keypad is great plus the waterproof-ness is handy since I am prone to spilling everything. The keys are 75% travel (guesstimate) so they take a bit of getting used to but the response on them is nice. Spongy, but not too spongy. I have an old mechanical server keyboard with a trackball built in and I love to use that for typing big things because the clicky-clacky is so nice to listen to. My parents below me disagree; hence the 'only using it sometimes'. Sidewinder macros are great for Photoshop; anyways.
tried the apple wireless kb today, feels good. however a bit reluctant to buy it since im using windows. anyone here uses apple kb on windows platform? comments?
http://www.nationalbarcode.com/Cherry/images/Cherry-G86-21050-Cymotion-Master-Express.jpg
the ibm model M is fantastic, but i work from home...
i switch between my unicomp and the leopold tenkeyless w/cherry red switches. i can't go back to non mechanical keyboards anymore...

@surajreddy How are those compared to the Apple Alu keyboards?  Generally speaking, the Apple alu keyboard (the wide one, I don't like the small one as much) is my favorite, though I'd love to try a quiet DasKeyboard at some point.

@maize Gotta admit, it's a little loud, but my 1987 IBM Model M keyboard (I believe one of the original PS/2 keyboards) has stood up to the test of time.. gotta love that real old-fashioned metal spring tactile response. Like you imply though, very loud and may not be acceptable in some office environments, so I use my Saitek Eclipse at work.
http://a1apc.com/zencart/images/6871.jpg
I have to say, my logitech ex 100 wireless keyboard and mouse have probably been the best I've had yet. It's not super fancy, but it gets the job done.
The wireless apple keyboard.
Hands down my Kinesis Advangage - http://www.kinesis-ergo.com/advantage.htm
@toonse I've always heard good things about that keyboard, though the price has been a little steep for me.

Bummer... I just found out the Frog Pad isn't in production anymore. When I fractured my hand when a car hit me, Frog Pad allowed me to keep coding: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FrogPad After I recovered, I found out it was a great keyboard for gaming!
IPHONE KEYBOARD!!
@barce dang, that's a pretty sweet keyboard. It really is too bad its not in production anymore. Ebay, here I come!
Using Microsoft Natural ergonomic 4000 keyboard since 2006.  Ergonomics, its kinda a big deal.
@toonse dude. that thing is a trip.
Macally Icekey is my favorite, it basically has the exact same keys as the older Macbook Pros: http://goo.gl/AvoZk
the thinkpad keyboard is the best keyboard evar.
I just got my Keytronic ergoforce back. Yay, lovin it again.  Shame they are not made anymore. http://de-img2.ciao.com/ide/images/products/normal/493/product-1294493.jpg
The one I am using...?
@tvon I haven't tired the apple alu keyboards. The apple ones are probably better, but I'm a macbook user and have no complaints with this one. It's also tons cheaper!

Since the conversation is still going on and an interesting collection of keyboard photos is being made, I'll say again "Goldtouch is great," and durable too (I commute w/it in a backback once a week, been using the same one a couple years).  Nice key travel, satisfying oldschool click (tho I think the newer versions do this less, which I really hate, so check ebay first).  Great for the RSI afflicted, can't praise it highly enough!  
http://www.waratuman.com/resources/images/posts/2010-10-25-goldtouch.jpeg

Apple Wired Keyboard. I wish they made a wireless version of it because I have issues with the the Fn keys taking the bottom left corner (where Ctrl usually is) and the tiny arrow keys (even mentioning this hurts my Vim cred but what the heck!). Having said that, I'll be getting wireless one soon to use it with the iPad. The keys and feel on Apple's (recent) keyboards are AMAZING!

http://www.surpluscomputers.com/348756/logitech-g15-gaming-backlit-keyboard.html easy to use and has macros that are quick to set up G-15 is great, I also ave the G-11 for travel, while that is big for a travel keyboard I can't help it since I can set it up almost like the G-15
Razer Lycosa http://www.amazon.com/Razer-Lycosa-Programmable-Backlit-Keyboard/dp/B000YDIA78/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1305320687&sr=8-1
Dvorak, any hardware.
@samengland That looks pretty sweet. I definitely would expect something like that to cost more.
thinkpad keyboards
x or t series

Logitech Cordless Desktop Pro: Split key design to fend off RSI and its wireless :) The layout takes a little while to get used to but it is much easier on the wrists once you do. (Same as with my Wacom Graphire 4 tablet instead of a mouse ;)
Cherry j82, the oldschool one
@jsarbour haha. I hate having fat fingers. :P

I use a Happy Hacker Professional (black) when I can, but since my wife complained that it's too loud and was disturbing the baby's sleeping, I have gone back to using my Apple Wireless keyboard.  The main thing for me is to have a narrow keyboard so my mousing arm isn't way off to the right.
I use my Model M keyboards
(We have a lot of them lying around here at IBM, I've managed to pick up three over the course of a year)
